name.text: 19.1.2.3 Arbitrary Constants in a Differential Equation

questiontext.text: We have seen that an expression including one arbitrary constant required one differentiation to obtain a differential equation which eliminated the arbitrary constant. Where two constants were present, two differentiations were required. Is the converse true? For example, would a differential equation involving \(\dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\) as the only derivative have a general solution with one arbitrary constant and would a differential equation which had \(\dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\) as the highest derivative produce a general solution with two arbitrary constants? The answer is, usually, yes.
